column3: description
Very easy workout meant for recovery, to allow the body to recover; should feel guilty for going easy.
Workout focused on maintaining a higher speed for longer while staying aerobic, such as running in heart‑rate Zone 2.
Even‑paced aerobic workout (e.g., zone 2 ride for several hours).
Harder effort close to a 10‑km race pace.
Training near the point where aerobic respiration shifts to anaerobic; improves lactate processing and glycogen conservation.
Workouts at VO2 max to improve oxygen usage, speed and power.
Important workout intended to cause a significant positive adaptation.
Doing one workout immediately after another (e.g., bike run) to prepare for triathlon transitions.
Best effort over a given distance or time to measure performance.
Short, easy‑paced run performed within 24 hours after a hard session; used for active recovery.
Short to moderate‑length run meant to be easy and done frequently for aerobic development.
Longest run of the week; comfortable pace to build endurance and familiarise the body and mind with race challenges.
Repeatedly running fast up a hill with slow jog/walk back; builds leg strength and running economy.
Run with pace increasing from beginning to end; combines endurance and speed.
Workout consisting of short distances at faster than normal pace with multiple repeats.
Run at a comfortably hard pace maintained for a longer period; slower than race pace.
Mix of low‑moderate and high‑intensity runs; short periods of fast effort followed by longer periods of jogging or walking.
Swedish for 'speed play'; similar to intervals but less structured; mixes jogging and sprinting or walking and running.
Speed workouts and drills, including short and long intervals, fartlek, hill workouts and tempo runs, to build speed.
Easy run based on how you feel to help recover at the highest quality possible after intense training.
Low‑intensity ride (RPE 0‑4) for 30‑60 minutes; like taking a walk on your bike; engages active recovery without training stress.
Easy endurance ride where intensity is centered in the endurance zone; enhances the body's ability to use fat as fuel.
Moderate intensity aerobic ride spanning endurance and tempo zones; maintain moderate effort for 60 minutes to 4 hours.
Unstructured, high‑intensity ride across all energy systems; simulates racing conditions; average intensity often falls in the tempo zone.
Intervals focusing effort on the lower end of the tempo zone; intensity just above the aerobic threshold but below lactate threshold.
Intervals working in the intensity between the top of the tempo zone and the bottom of the threshold zone to improve threshold power and endurance.
Threshold zone intervals aimed at improving lactate threshold power; strenuous but effective for increasing FTP.
Threshold‑based intervals that alternate between slightly below and slightly above threshold (FTP) to improve race specificity.
Intervals at the top of the threshold zone to replicate climbing or time trial efforts; sustained maximal effort for 6‑15 minutes.
Threshold intervals that finish with a surge into VO2 max; used to practice punching over climbs.
Short 2‑5‑minute intervals at near maximal intensity to improve maximal aerobic power and VO2 max.
Very short intervals (20‑40 seconds) with short recovery; high‑intensity to stress aerobic and anaerobic systems.
Intervals of 30‑90 seconds performed at maximum output to develop anaerobic power; rely on glycolytic energy pathway.
High‑intensity interval training in the pool; 30‑60 seconds of fast swimming at 85–90 % effort followed by equal rest; improves VO2 max and is enjoyable.
All‑out sprint intervals of under 30 seconds with long rest (~4 minutes); extremely high intensity.
Repeated sprints of about 10 seconds with relatively short rest (~60 seconds); improves speed and power; involves many reps.
Ultra‑short race pace training: many repetitions at race pace with short rest; if pace is missed, rest or stop; designed to train race pace and technique.
Eight rounds of 20 seconds all‑out effort followed by 10 seconds rest; total set duration four minutes; extremely intense and improves VO2 max.
Continuous swimming with random bursts of speed; Swedish for 'speed play'; increases breathing capacity and teaches gear changes; more engaging than steady‑state swimming.
Longer, sustained intervals lasting several minutes with less velocity than sprint training; builds endurance and improves technique.
Easy swimming for recovery instead of resting at the wall, providing continuous aerobic effect while muscles recover.
Set in which each successive repeat is faster than the last; encourages progressive speed increase.
Exercises where muscles generate force while changing length (concentric and eccentric contractions).
Muscle shortens while generating force (e.g., lifting the weight in a bicep curl).
Muscle lengthens while under tension to decelerate movement or control the load (e.g., lowering the weight).
Exercises where muscles generate force without changing length, such as holding a plank or gripping an object.
Explosive body‑weight exercises using the stretch‑shortening cycle; quick pre‑stretch followed by powerful concentric contraction to develop maximal force quickly.
Workout method involving rotating through multiple exercises targeting different muscle groups with little or no rest; can be repetition, timed, competition or sport‑specific circuits.
Exercises aimed at strengthening muscles that stabilize the trunk, hips and shoulders to protect the spine and transfer force; emphasizes creating 360° stiffness around the spine.
